title: What are the state schools called in England? - Quora

response.answer_text: As you asked I will answer specifically for England (and, so an extent, Wales and Northern Ireland) because it is very different in Scotland (education was one of a small group of things not included in the 1707 Act of Union, so the Scots education system is totally different). Anyway, at the broadest level, state schools in England are called… “state schools”. Never, ever “public schools” - a “public school” is the very antithesis of a “state school”. For age purposes, these are divided into “primary” and “secondary”, the former for ages 5–11, the latter for 11–16, though many primaries have “nurseries” which start children as young as 3, and many secondaries have “sixth forms” for 16–18 year olds. Some areas have “first” and “middle” schools instead of primaries, and “upper” schools instead of secondaries, for ages 5–8, 8–13 and 13–18, but legally middle schools will be “deemed” either primary or secondary. You can divide secondaries into two categories - selective and non-selective (or “comprehensive”), with the former divided into “grammar” and “secondary modern”. However almost all secondaries are now non-selective, and even some “grammar schools” are now non-selective. Traditionally (well, since 1944*) schools have also been “county”, “voluntary aided” or “voluntary controlled” which tends/tended to mean who owned the physical building. County schools were owned by the Local Education Authority (LEA) (normally the county council), while voluntary schools were owned by someone else (most often a church). Of the voluntary schools, in “aided” schools the buildings were also maintained by the owners, which gave them all sorts of extra management and curriculum rights, whereas “controlled” schools were maintained by the LEA, and had few extra rights. Aided schools also tended to be Roman Catholic, and controlled schools tended to be Church of England, but there are hundreds of exceptions to that. But now it’s not as easy as that as schools now come with a blizzard of different names thanks to a riot of different government initiatives which can make things really, really confusing. For example, many schools are now called “academies”, which means that are not part of their LEA but financed directly by central government, and are even freer from the rules than Aided schools. In addition some schools now call themselves “colleges” or “technical colleges” or “village colleges” or even “university technical colleges”, even (in some cases) if they are just primary schools (which emphasises the meaninglessness of the word “college” in England). [*Before 1944 schools tended to be “elementary” (for ages 5 to the then school leaving age, 14) or “secondary”, which were in practice almost all selective grammar schools.]
